**INSTITUTION
Discharge Summary
Name :
**NAME[AAA , BBB]
Acct # :
**ID-NUM
MRN :
**ID-NUM
Admitted :
**DATE[Feb 10 2007]
Discharged :
**DATE[Feb 17 2007]
Dict :
**NAME[XXX , WWW]
Attend :
**NAME[ZZZ , YYY]
DISCHARGE DIAGNOSES :
PRIMARY DIAGNOSIS :
Left buttock hematoma .
SECONDARY DIAGNOSES :
1. Multiple myeloma , stage IIIB immunoglobulin M lambda .
2. Hypertension .
3. History of atrial fibrillation .
4. History of hyperlipidemia .
5. History of diverticulitis .
STUDIES / PROCEDURES :
1. Hematoma evacuation by orthopedic surgery , Dr. **NAME[VVV] was done on **DATE[Feb 12 2007] .
Irrigation and debridement of the left buttock hematoma .
2. Bilateral lower extremity Dopplers were done on **DATE[Feb 13 2007] , showing no evidence of DVT in either leg .
3. Lower extremity MRI of the left leg showing changes consistent with a partially evacuated hematoma .
No specific features of abscess , although superinfection could not be excluded on the basis of that imaging study .
There was moderate , strandy edema or hemorrhage within the adductor muscles and the posterior compartment .
Also , multiple foci of marrow replacement within the pelvis was seen , most likely related to the known multiple myeloma without pathologic fracture .
Chest x-ray on **DATE[Feb 11 2007] , showed no active disease .
**INSTITUTION ADMISSION :
This is a **AGE[in 50s]- year - old man with a past medical history significant for stage IIIB immunoglobulin M lambda multiple myeloma who was admitted on **DATE[Feb 10 2007] , for an intramuscular hematoma while taking Lovenox after a bone marrow biopsy .
Bone marrow biopsy was done on **DATE[Feb 5 2007] .
HOSPITAL COURSE :
1. Hematoma .
On admission , the patient has severe pain and limited range of motion at his left hip secondary to the left buttock hematoma .
Initially , the anticoagulation with Lovenox was stopped .
Pain was initially controlled with MS Contin and IV Dilaudid for breakthrough pain .
However , later , his pain required a Dilaudid PCA for optimal control .
The patient was seen by Dr. **NAME[VVV] from orthopedics on **DATE[Feb 11 2007] , and then taken to the OR on
**DATE[Feb 12 2007] , for evacuation of the hematoma .
His postoperative course was complicated by :
2. Series of fevers on day 1 postoperatively .
These were worked up with lower extremity Dopplers which were negative ; and MRI of the lower extremity which was also negative for any sort of abscess .
Dr. **NAME[UUU] from infectious diseases was also consulted , and intravenous antibiotics with Zosyn and vancomycin were also initiated .
However , all cultures were negative .
By postoperative day 2 to 3 , all of the fevers had resolved .
Therefore , the fever was likely due to postoperative atelectasis which is the most common cause of day 1 postoperative fever .
This was treated with incentive spirometry .
3. Infectious diseases .
As stated above , there was a question of an infected hematoma .
However , the MRI of the leg did not show any sort of abscess .
Dr. **NAME[UUU] from infectious diseases was consulted .
The patient was treated with IV Zosyn and vancomycin for 6 and 5 days respectively .
Cultures from the Hemovac and blood cultures all remained negative .
There was no other explanation for the fever .
There was no UTI .
The chest x-ray did not show any pneumonia .
On discharge , he was put on Augmentin for approximately 9 more days .
4. Multiple myeloma .
This was diagnosed in **DATE[Nov 2006] with a presentation of back pain and serum viscosity of 15 .
He received DT - PACE x 1 cycle with refractory disease , then 3 cycles of Velcade , thalidomide , and dexamethasone .
However , the thalidomide was held for two cycles secondary to atrial fibrillation .
The long - term plan is for autologous stem cell transplant .
This will be addressed as an outpatient by Dr. **NAME[ZZZ] .
On this admission , his IgM was still high at 6240 .
Dr. **NAME[VVV] requests that chemotherapy with Velcade be held until after his office appointment in approximately 2 weeks in order to monitor the progress of the evacuation of the hematoma prior to restarting chemotherapy .
5. Cardiovascular. Dr. **NAME[TTT] with cardiology was consulted for clearance prior to autologous stem cell transplant .
The patient had not been in atrial fibrillation since thalidomide had been discontinued and a recent stress test from an outside hospital was negative for ischemia and had normal wall motion .
Therefore , Dr. **NAME[TTT] cleared Mr. **NAME[CCC] for stem cell transplant once these acute issues have resolved .
His atenolol was continued throughout hospitalization .
DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS :
1. Vitamin C 500 mg p.o. daily .
2. Atenolol 25 mg p.o. daily .
3. Lipitor 40 mg p.o. nightly .
4. Neurontin 300 mg p.o. q.8 h .
5. Dilaudid 1 mg p.o. q.4 h. p.r.n. pain .
6. MS Contin 60 mg p.o. q.12 h .
7. Protonix 40 mg p.o. daily .
8. Senna two tablets p.o. nightly .
9. Bactrim DS one tablet p.o. b.i.d. Monday , Wednesday , and Friday .
10. Lovenox 40 mg subcutaneously daily .
11. Augmentin 875 mg p.o. b.i.d. for 9 days .
The decision to restart Lovenox was discussed with Dr. **NAME[VVV] 's resident , and it was determined that prophylactic doses of Lovenox were safe for now .
DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS :
1. Diet , heart healthy .
2. Activity as tolerated .
DISPOSITION :
Discharged to home .
CONDITION :
Fair to good .
Home occupational and physical therapy via **INSTITUTION Health .
PICC line care via Chartwell .
FOLLOWUP APPOINTMENTS :
1. Dr. **NAME[VVV] orthopedics , scheduled for **DATE[Feb 29 2007] at 4:15 p.m.
Phone number **PHONE .
2. Dr. **NAME[ZZZ] .
The patient was instructed by Dr. **NAME[ZZZ] to call the office on Friday **DATE[Feb 19 2007] , to make a followup appointment for Wednesday **DATE[Feb 24 2007] .
______________________________
**NAME[WWW XXX]
